author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Calif. bans schools from using controversial football name
text:
SAUL LOEB/AFP/Getty Images The movement to do away with a controversial football team name gains steam in California, where Governor Jerry Brown bans public schools from using the moniker. LOS ANGELES (AP) — Four California schools will be forced to change mascots after Gov. Jerry Brown signed legislation barring public schools from using a controversial team name for sports teams.
It was one of three sports-related bills Brown recently approved. He also signed a measure that bans using or possessing smokeless tobacco on the playing field at professional baseball parks and another that recognizes competitive cheerleading as a high school sport.
The mascot legislation will prevent public schools from using a term that American Indians regard as offensive. It goes into effect in 2017.
Only four schools still use the name, which is also used by the NFL's Washington franchise. Messages seeking comment from school officials were not immediately returned Monday, a federal holiday.
Brown rejected separate legislation that bans naming parks, schools and other public property after Confederate leaders.
